metadata.case_name: Patna Electric Supply Co., Ltd. v. Patna Electric Supply Workers Union

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from judgment and order dated January 31, 1956, of the Labour Appellate Tribunal of India, Calcutta, in Appeals Nos. Cal. 36 and 38 of 1953.
Appellant is a public company incorporated under Indian Companies Act, registered office at Patna, engaged in public utility service of electricity supply, licensee under Electric Supply Act, 1948.

On March 29, 1952, Government of Bihar referred twelve items of dispute to Industrial Tribunal (Mr. H. K. Chaudhuri sole member) under s.7 read with s.10 of Industrial Disputes Act, 1947; dispute concerns housing facilities and principle of allotment of quarters.
Respondent demanded appellant provide houses to employees and construct quarters immediately per Bihar Government scheme.
Appellant denied liability to provide housing, claimed primary responsibility of State, financially impossible, restricted by Electricity Supply Act, 1948.

Industrial Tribunal on March 9, 1953, upheld respondent's claim, directed appellant to start construction of at least 15 quarters per Government scheme specifications within one year of award publication.
Labour Appellate Tribunal dismissed appellant's appeal on January 31, 1956, held Bihar Government scheme binding, expenditure admissible under Electricity Act.
Supreme Court granted special leave on September 17, 1956.
Appellant voluntarily provides housing to some: 17/183 Power Station, 146/329 Mains Dept., 1/58 General Dept. free quarters; 1 Mains Dept. employee gets house allowance at 12.5%.
Bihar Labour Enquiry Committee (1938, Ch. Dr. Rajendra Prasad) recommended statutory housing obligation on employers based on financial condition; no action taken.
Industrial Housing Sub-Committee report Dec 16, 1948; reconsidered Aug 17, 1950; adopted by Bihar Central Standing Labour Advisory Board Sep 1950 with modifications; sanctioned by State Government.
Bihar scheme: Employers responsible for housing; State gives 50% loan at 3% interest, repayable in 25 years; prescribes letting terms, sizes, specs; recommendatory.
No representative of appellant on committee when scheme adopted in 1950; Mr. Chandra (Labour Adviser, also for other companies) joined in 1952.

legal_issues.text: Whether the direction issued by the award calling upon the appellant to start construction of at least 15 quarters is justified.
Whether the Bihar Government scheme imposes a moral obligation on employers enforceable by industrial adjudication.
Whether industrial tribunal has jurisdiction, apart from the scheme, to direct employer to provide housing accommodation.

petitioner_arguments.text: Housing facilities primary responsibility of State, not employer; financially impossible; not permitted by Electricity Supply Act, 1948.
Voluntary housing provision is matter of choice, not obligation or term of employment.
Bihar scheme not binding; no consent by appellant; recommendatory only.

respondent_arguments.text: Appellant bound to provide quarters per Bihar Government scheme; imposes moral obligation enforceable in industrial adjudication.
Industrial adjudication can impose new obligations for social justice; tribunal can direct housing as employees need it.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Ludwig Teller on industrial arbitration; precedents like Western India Automobile

court_reasoning.text: Bihar scheme has no statutory force, merely recommendatory; State offers financial assistance if employer chooses to build; no basis for enforcing direction.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Scheme sanctioned but no action on statutory obligation recommendation; no consent by appellant.

court_reasoning.text: Industrial tribunals consistently hold housing primary State responsibility; inexpedient to impose on employers given economic conditions; wages/dearness allowance account for rent.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Cited multiple tribunal decisions refusing housing or separate house allowance claims.

court_reasoning.text: Though tribunals have jurisdiction to create new obligations for industrial peace/social justice, not justified here due to national economy, industry finances.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Imposition may burden industry, affect progress, passed to consumers increasing prices.

court_reasoning.text: No consideration of appellant's financial ability; tribunals erred assuming scheme binding.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Proceeds on theoretical considerations ignoring facts.

holdings.text: Scheme cannot justify direction to construct quarters; no term of employment introduced.
Under present conditions, no jurisdiction to direct housing apart from scheme; primary State responsibility.
Award cannot be sustained; set aside.

precedents_cited.case_name: Western India Automobile Association v. The Industrial Tribunal, Bombay
precedents_cited.relevance: Industrial adjudication not bound by strict master-servant law; can direct reinstatement.

precedents_cited.case_name: The Bharat Bank Ltd., Delhi v. The Employees of the Bharat Bank Ltd., Delhi
precedents_cited.relevance: Tribunal can confer new rights/obligations for industrial peace.

precedents_cited.case_name: Rohtas Industries Ltd. v. Brijnandan Pandey
precedents_cited.relevance: Tribunal not fettered like courts; can create/modify obligations for peace.

precedents_cited.case_name: Eastern Plywood Manufacturing Co., Ltd. And Their Workers
precedents_cited.relevance: Rejected housing/house rent allowance; considered in wages/DA.

precedents_cited.case_name: Mahomad Rai Akbarali Khan v. The Associated Cement Companies Ltd.
precedents_cited.relevance: Housing not employer's duty; readjust DA for rent; even in rural impact areas.

precedents_cited.case_name: Samastipur Central Sugar Co., Ltd., And Their Workmen
precedents_cited.relevance: House rent presumed in consolidated wage/DA.

precedents_cited.case_name: Messrs. National Carbon Co. India Ltd. v. National Carbon Co., Mazdoor Union, Calcutta
precedents_cited.relevance: No jurisdiction for house allowance when dispute is free quarters.

statutes_cited.name: Electric Supply Act, 1948
statutes_cited.relevance: Appellant licensee; alleged to restrict housing expenditure (not decided).

statutes_cited.name: Plantations Labour Act, 1951
statutes_cited.relevance: Statutory housing duty for plantation employers.

outcome.summary: Appeal succeeds; award of Industrial Tribunal directing construction of 15 quarters and Labour Appellate Tribunal's dismissal set aside; no obligation on appellant to provide housing per scheme or otherwise.

key_quotes.text: "industrial adjudication does not mean adjudication according to the strict law of master and servant."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "The scheme in question on which the respondent relies has no statutory force. It merely approves of the recommendations..."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Rejects binding nature of Bihar scheme.

key_quotes.text: "industrial tribunals have consistently refused to entertain a claim for housing accommodation or for the grant of a special and separate housing allowance"
key_quotes.speaker: court
